The Museum of Modern Art (MoMA) in New York City has received a gift of more than 1,500 photographs by artist and photographer Stanley Elmore, including some of his most famous works, The Golden Atrocity, 1910, which has been the subject of three separate exhibitions at the museum. The first, a retrospective that ran in 2004, was entitled “Stanley Elmore: Icon,” and featured works by Elmore, Foster and Wes Anderson, and Paul Gauguin. The second, a retrospective that focused on photography as a medium in 2007, “Stanley Elmore: Photographs,” was organized by the Los Angeles County Museum of Art (LACMA), and was presented by the Los Angeles–based artist and curator Roddy McDowall.
